entry.title: Re: Scheduling dashboard- Does not move preceding orders...
entry.content:
To get more clarity, would like to ask few questions as under

  • Is this behavior impacting production efficiency, setup times, or delivery priorities?
  • Is there a business rule that defines which orders should move together?
  • Are we using pegging or setup group dependencies that could be leveraged?
  • what is the need to look for some alternative, assuming when user move the order in between, no impact on the business right?

Of course, some workarounds are there

  • In the DS Planning Board, you can select multiple orders and move them together. This preserves their relative sequence and avoids pushing the moved order to the end.
  • After moving the order, run a heuristic like SAP_PP_019 (Reschedule Orders) to re-optimize the sequence. This may help realign the preceding orders if capacity permits.

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI Excel update and upload
entry.content: While you can mass update all the fields like MRP Type, Short Text and Storage Bin, Internal Comment is not possible.  Either you can try with LSMW or BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEREPLICA.  Take the help of your ABAP team who can help on this Internal Comment, to mass upload

entry.title: Re: CS20/CEWB - Adding new component to existing BOMs
entry.content:
If you have a list of BOMs (e.g., in Excel), you can use the below apaproaches

  • Create a recording for CS01 or CS02 to add the new component to each BOM individually or
  • Use BAPI_MATERIAL_BOM_GROUP_CREATE or BAPI_MATERIAL_BOM_GROUP_CHANGE to programmatically add the component to each BOM.

This gives you full control over which BOMs are updated and allows you to include additional logic (e.g., usage, quantity, validity dates).

If this is a recurring need, your technical team can build a custom ABAP program that:

  • Accepts a list of BOMs (e.g., from a file or selection screen)
  • Adds the component using standard function modules like CSAP_MAT_BOM_UPDATE

This is ideal for automation and auditability.

entry.title: Re: Meetup Fortaleza 2025 - Agosto
entry.content:
Ontem tivemos mais um passo importante na preparação do SAP Inside Track Fortaleza, que acontecerá em 25 de outubro de 2025. Nossa reunião de organização trouxe definições que tornam este evento ainda mais especial:

1- Hands-on inéditos: teremos três sessões práticas – SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Datasphere e WalkMe – em paralelo ao evento principal. Cada um com inscrição separada (disponível apenas para quem já adquiriu ingresso).

2- Mais vagas liberadas : com a ampliação do espaço, conseguimos disponibilizar 30 novas inscrições, atendendo às solicitações da comunidade após o esgotamento inicial.

3- Apresentação cultural : as crianças da instituição Estação da Luz irão emocionar com uma apresentação musical. Estamos cuidando de toda a logística para recebê-las com carinho.

4- Agenda confirmada: as palestras presenciais estão fechadas, mas ainda é possível submeter propostas para as sessões online que ocorrerão na semana anterior ao evento.

5- Infraestrutura do evento: coffee-break definido e almoço garantido para palestrantes, organização e voluntários.

6- Comunicação visual: novos banners e identidade visual do SIT Fortaleza estão a caminho, trazendo modernidade e reforçando a marca do evento.

Este encontro terminou às 22h30, com a energia de sempre da comunidade que constrói junto cada detalhe.

O SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2025 promete ser um marco – conhecimento, colaboração e impacto social lado a lado.

#SAPCommunity #SITFortaleza #SAPInsideTrack #SAP

-----------------------------------------

EN

Yesterday we had another important step in the preparation of SAP Inside Track Fortaleza, which will take place on October 25, 2025. Our organization meeting brought exciting updates that will make this edition even more special:

1- Hands-on sessions: three practical workshops will be part of the event – SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC), Datasphere, and WalkMe. These will run in parallel with the main track, with separate registration (available only for ticket holders).

2- Extra tickets released : with the event expansion, we are happy to announce 30 additional seats, answering the many requests after tickets were sold out.

3- Cultural presentation : children from the Estação da Luz social initiative will deliver a touching musical performance. Transportation and meals will be provided so they can fully enjoy the day.

5- Event logistics: coffee breaks are set, and lunch will be provided for speakers, organizers, and volunteers.

6- Visual identity: new banners and a refreshed design for SAP Inside Track Fortaleza are being finalized to bring a modern touch to the event.

The meetup wrapped up at 10:30 PM, filled with the same community energy that drives us forward in every detail.

SAP Inside Track Fortaleza 2025 promises to be a remarkable gathering – combining knowledge, collaboration, and social impact.

entry.title: Re: change recipe with change number
entry.content:
Below are some common reasons why Recipe Object is Grayed Out

When creating the change number (transaction CC01), you must include the correct object type — in this case, recipe (usually RECIPE or RECP depending on your system). If the object type isn’t selected or is incorrect, the recipe field will be disabled later.

Even if the profile includes “recipe,” it might be tailored for master recipes or general recipes, and not the specific type you're working with.

Check the change profile configuration in SPRO → Logistics → Central Functions → Engineering Change Management → Define Change Profiles. Make sure the profile allows changes to the recipe type you're editing.

The recipe itself might not be flagged for Engineering Change Management. Check the recipe in C202/C203 and see if it’s linked to a change number or if ECM is active for that recipe type.

entry.content: Hey! Don’t worry, we’ve all been there when learning SAP 😊. You can usually update fields like MRP Type, Short Text, Storage Bin, and Internal Comment via transaction codes like MM02 for material master. Just make sure to have the proper authorizations before mass changes.

entry.title: Re: Production process
entry.content:
Hello @AngelT 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, cut-to-length rods, cables, and sheets are not modelled as standard production since the PP logic assumes 1:1 input/output.

Best practice setup:

Base UoM: Use metre as the base unit of measure (stock 6.000 m per rod; sales consume 1m, 2m, etc.). If the base unit of measure equals piece, assign a batch characteristic, Remaining Length, to capture the actual length.

Inventory handling: Use batch split on goods issue to reflect cuts like 1m + 5m. This prevents the proliferation of material masters. Optionally, utilise Handling Unit Management for physical processes. piece tracking.

Execution: Cutting is regarded as an inventory split or rework, not production. If traceability is needed, use a Rework or Conversion order (input 6m → output 1m + 5m) instead of BOM/Routing.

Valuation: System posts proportional cost to each split batch, ensuring correct inventory value.

Optional: For configurable customer orders, LO-VC can be used to capture length dynamically.

Recommendation: Use base UoM in meters, along with batch characteristics and batch split, for leftover tracking. Model cutting as an inventory process or rework order, not as a standard production order

Reference: SAP Help – Batch Management in S/4HANA Cloud

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Conect to sap b1 10.00.110 via DI aPI
entry.content:
Hello @cbarreto @Lucidio 

Here’s a precise checklist and a corrected connection snippet for SAP Business One 10.00.110 via DI API. Error -132 (Error during SBO user authentication) almost always boils down to one of the items below.

What to fix/check (in order)

Version/patch match (critical)

  • The DI API version must match the server patch (or be the exact same Feature Package level).
  • If your app machine has 10.00.170 DI API but the server/company DB is 10.00.110, install the 10.00.110 DI API on the app machine (and reference that).
  • Also ensure 32-bit vs 64-bit matches your application target (x86 app → 32-bit DI API; x64 app → 64-bit DI API).

License Server must be set

  • Always set LicenseServer = "<host>:30000" where <host> is the SAP Business One License Manager host (not SQL host unless they’re the same machine).

Pick ONE DB authentication mode

  • If you set UseTrusted = true, do not set DbUserName/DbPassword. The DI API will try Windows authentication for SQL Server.
  • If you want SQL authentication (most common), set UseTrusted = false and provide valid DbUserName/DbPassword (SQL login with rights on SBO-COMMON and the company DB).

Company user is SAP B1 user (not SQL)

  • UserName/Password are SAP Business One credentials (e.g., manager).
  • Verify that user can log in with the SAP Business One Client 10.00.110 to that same company and is not locked / password expired by policy.

Server/Instance and DB type

  • Server must be the SQL Server host (and instance if named), e.g. "10.10.50.101\\SQL2017" (double backslash in C# string).
  • DbServerType must match exactly (e.g., dst_MSSQL2017).

SBO-COMMON & Company DB state

  • Ensure the target CompanyDB is upgraded to 10.00.110 and SBO-COMMON is consistent. Log in once with the B1 client to confirm no pending upgrades.

Network/DNS basics

  • If using IP fails, try the machine name; ensure no firewall blocks to License Server (TCP 30000) and SQL (default 1433 or instance port).

Corrected sample (C#)

using SAPbobsCOM;

 

public Company ConnectB1()

{

    var oCompany = new Company

    {

        // SQL Server host (add instance if needed, e.g. "10.10.50.101\\SQL2017")

        Server = "10.10.50.101",

        DbServerType = BoDataServerTypes.dst_MSSQL2017,

 

        // Company database

        CompanyDB = "TEST_COMPANY",

 

        // SAP Business One user credentials (NOT SQL)

        UserName = "manager",

        Password = "******",

 

        // Use SQL authentication for DB (common)

        UseTrusted = false,

        DbUserName = "sql_user",

        DbPassword = "sql_password",

 

        // MUST point to the B1 License Server host:30000

        LicenseServer = "B1-LIC-HOST:30000",

 

        language = BoSuppLangs.ln_English

    };

 

    int rc = oCompany.Connect();

    if (rc != 0)

    {

        oCompany.GetLastError(out int errCode, out string errMsg);

        throw new ApplicationException($"DI API connect failed: {errCode} - {errMsg}");

    }

 

    return oCompany;

}

 

If you really need Windows (trusted) auth:

UseTrusted = true;

// Do NOT set DbUserName/DbPassword in this case.

// Ensure the Windows account running the process has SQL access to SBO-COMMON and the company DB.

Fast diagnostics for -132

  • Works on 10.00.170 but fails on 10.00.110 → Almost always DI API patch mismatch or LicenseServer not set.
  • Can log in with B1 client, but DI API fails → Check LicenseServer, auth mode (trusted vs SQL), Server\Instance string.
  • Still failing → Try the exact same B1 user in the client on the same machine; if prompted to change password or locked, fix that first.

Let me know if you need further support

with kind regards

Chuma

 

 

GenAI assist content(Reference Articles and Guides for helpful information and guidance)

  • Troubleshooting SAP Business One DI Server Issues
  • SAP Community - Using DI API Connections
  • SAP Business One DI API Troubleshooting Guide - Praxis Info Solutions

entry.title: Understanding the read-only flag and how to solve MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA
entry.content:
I had a few difficulties after refactoring some code via Extract Method in ADT (Ctrl+Shift+M), I thought that it was a safe operation, which should not lead to regressions, but the code failed with errors like the exception class CX_SY_DYN_CALL_ILLEGAL_TYPE or the runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA.

These errors are due to the read-only flag which is set at runtime on data objects (importing parameters by reference, internal table key fields, explicit READ-ONLY public class attributes).

I will try to explain what this internal flag is, and how to work around this limitation.

 

The internal read-only flag is set either at runtime or at compile times, as follows:

  1. “The key fields of the primary table key of sorted tables and hashed tables are always read-only.” Source: https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_758_index_htm/7.58/en-US/index.htm?file=abenitab_key_primary.htm.
  2. For methods and function modules, “Input parameters for which pass by reference is defined must not be accessed with write access in the procedure.” Source: https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_758_index_htm/7.58/en-US/index.htm?file=abeninput_parameter_glosry.htm.
  3. The direct access to a public class attribute defined explicitly as READ-ONLY, from outside the class. Source: https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_758_index_htm/7.58/en-US/index.htm?file=abapdata_options.htm#!ABAP_ADDITION_2@2@. The attribute can be changed if the attribute is accessed from inside the class or from a friend class, and it remains ignored if this class or friend class passes the attribute by reference to a procedure outside the class or friend class.
  4. If a reference is created from a read-only field obtained by one of the three previous cases, it inherits the internal read-only flag (whatever it's off or on).

 

CX_SY_DYN_CALL_ILLEGAL_TYPE when calling a method

I wanted to refactor this code:

    DATA mandants TYPE SORTED TABLE OF t000 WITH UNIQUE KEY mandt.
    mandants = VALUE #( ( mandt = '100' mtext = ' test' ) ).
    LOOP AT mandants ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<mandant>).
      <mandant>-mtext = condense( <mandant>-mtext ).
    ENDLOOP.

I refactored the code by applying Extract Method to the line inside the loop. The method CONDENSE_MANDANT_TEXT was created:

    DATA mandants TYPE SORTED TABLE OF t000 WITH UNIQUE KEY mandt.
    mandants = VALUE #( ( mandt = '100' mtext = ' test' ) ).
    LOOP AT mandants ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<mandant>).
      condense_mandant_text( CHANGING c_mandant = <mandant> ).
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD condense_mandant_text.
    c_mandant-mtext = condense( c_mandant-mtext ).
  ENDMETHOD.

When running this refactored code, the exception CX_SY_DYN_CALL_ILLEGAL_TYPE happens when attempting to call the method CONDENSE_MANDANT_TEXT (it’s not even called).

This CX_SY_DYN_CALL_ILLEGAL_TYPE exception had this message: "Call of the method CONDENSE_MANDANT_TEXT of the class LCL_APP has failed; the actual parameter for C_MANDANT is write-protected"

This error happened due to the fact that the internal table MANDANTS is of type « SORTED » (it would also happen with « HASHED ») with key field MANDT, so this key field is implicitly read-only.

 

There are two workarounds:

1/ The “easiest” (*) way: change the internal table primary key to STANDARD and use a secondary key instead.

    DATA mandants TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t000 WITH EMPTY KEY
                  WITH UNIQUE SORTED KEY by_mandt COMPONENTS mandt.

Be careful, a unique secondary key may be a problem if one of its key fields is updated, it would lead to the runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA. If that’s the case, see the next chapter.

(*) In fact, this solution is not so easy because moving a key from primary to secondary may change the behavior like a duplicate unique key may not be seen immediately if a Delayed Update happens (see Delayed Update: https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_758_index_htm/7.58/en-US/index.htm?file=abenitab_key_secondary_update.htm). You also have to verify all reads of the internal table and indicate explicitly if needed the use of the secondary key (e.g. mandants[ KEY by_mandt COMPONENTS mandt = '100' ]). See also the recommendations when to use or not to use secondary keys: https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_758_index_htm/7.58/en-US/index.htm?file=abenitab_key_secondary_usage.htm.

 

2/ The second solution is to transfer the whole internal table instead of one line i.e., refactor the whole loop:

    condense_all_mandant_texts( CHANGING c_mandants = mandants ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD condense_all_mandant_texts.
    LOOP AT c_mandants ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<mandant>).
      <mandant>-mtext = condense( <mandant>-mtext ).
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

 

Runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA Assignment error: Overwriting of a protected field.

The examples below all lead to the runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA if the sorted or hashed internal table has a primary key:

DATA mandants TYPE SORTED TABLE OF t000 WITH UNIQUE KEY mandt.

1/ Because it’s a key field:

mandants[ 1 ]-mandt = '100'. " Runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA

OR

DATA(ref_mandant) = REF #( mandants[ 1 ] ).
ref_mandant->mandt = '100'. " Runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA

 

NB: in both cases, it’s possible to maintain any non-key field e.g., MTEXT:

mandants[ 1 ]-mtext = test'. " No error
ref_mandant->mtext = test'. " No error

 

2/ Because the whole line is updated and contains a key field, although the key field is “changed to the same value”:

    DATA(new_mandant) = VALUE t000( mandt = '100' mtext = ' test 2' ).
    mandants[ 1 ] = new_mandant. " Runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA

 

3/ Because the reference was obtained from an importing parameter:

DATA(ref_mandant) = get_mandant_reference( mandants[ 1 ] ).
ref_mandant->mtext = 'test'. " Runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA

    METHODS get_mandant_reference
      IMPORTING i_mandant TYPE t000 " i_mandant is assigned the read-only flag
      RETURNING VALUE(r_ref_mandant) TYPE REF TO t000.

  METHOD get_mandant_reference.
    r_ref_mandant = REF #( i_mandant ). " the reference inherits the read-only flag from i_mandant
  ENDMETHOD.

 

The only workaround for changing the key fields in the case 1, is to change the internal table primary key to STANDARD (or any key which doesn’t contain the key fields to update) and use a secondary key instead, which lead to either a Lazy Update (non-unique secondary key) or a Delayed Update (unique secondary key, but the update must be done only via a data reference or a field symbol).

    DATA mandants TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF t000 WITH EMPTY KEY
                  WITH UNIQUE SORTED KEY by_mandt COMPONENTS mandt.

The change of a key field will update the secondary index only the next time the internal table is read. This will NOT produce a runtime error:

    mandants = VALUE #( ( mandt = '100' mtext = ' test' )
                        ( mandt = '110' mtext = 'test 2' ) ).
    DATA(ref_mandant) = REF #( mandants[ 1 ] ).
    DATA(ref_mandant_2) = REF #( mandants[ 2 ] ).
    ref_mandant->mandt = '110'.
    ref_mandant_2->mandt = '100'.

For more information about Lazy Update and Delayed Update, see: https://help.sap.com/doc/abapdocu_758_index_htm/7.58/en-US/index.htm?file=abenitab_key_secondary_update.htm.

Be careful, the next statement leads to the runtime error ITAB_DUPLICATE_KEY because it’s a unique key and the change is done neither via a data reference nor via a field-symbol and so the index is updated immediately instead of using a Delayed Update:

mandants[ 1 ]-mandt = '110'.

 

In the case 2, it’s possible to use MODIFY TABLE to avoid the runtime error, it ignores the key fields:

MODIFY TABLE mandants FROM new_mandant.

If you know the line index to update (sorted tables only), you may also use the line index number, provided that the key values are equal to the ones of the modified line (otherwise, the runtime error ITAB_ACTIVE_KEY_VIOLATION happens):

MODIFY mandants INDEX 1 FROM new_mandant.

 

In the case 3, you may use CHANGING instead of IMPORTING to be able to write to the data reference:

DATA(ref_mandant) = get_mandant_reference( CHANGING c_mandant = mandants[ 1 ] ).
ref_mandant->mtext = 'test'. " No runtime error

    METHODS get_mandant_reference
      CHANGING c_mandant TYPE t000
      RETURNING VALUE(r_ref_mandant) TYPE REF TO t000.

  METHOD get_mandant_reference.
    r_ref_mandant = REF #( c_mandant ).
  ENDMETHOD.

 

Compiler warning: The "ITAB" is key table. Writes cannot be performed on a full row and produce runtime errors.

For information, the compiler may send a warning if it detects an attempt to change a line from an internal table with a sorted or hashed primary key e.g., it can be any of these two situations:

condense_mandant_text( CHANGING c_mandant = mandants[ 1 ] ). " Exception CX_SY_DYN_CALL_ILLEGAL_TYPE
mandants[ 1 ] = new_mandant. " Runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA

The warning (that’s the message MESSAGEGJO in table TRMSG): The "MANDANTS" is key table. Writes cannot be performed on a full row and produce runtime errors.

It’s a warning but if the code above runs, it systematically raises an exception or a runtime error.

 

Conclusion

As far as I understand, the parameters, references or field symbols are each made of:

  • A pointer to a data object i.e., the value of a variable or constant. This pointer is probably the memory offset, possibly the length.
  • Read-only flag (true or false)
  • Internal table to which the data belongs (if applicable). It helps the system know which are the key fields and what index to update if a key field is changed.
  • NB: unrelated to read-only, a fourth attribute could be considered, which is the data type, either the original one or the one obtained via casting (ASSIGN CASTING).

After this blog post, you should know:

  • That Extract Method can lead to regressions
  • How the read-only flag works
  • How to avoid and solve the exception CX_SY_DYN_CALL_ILLEGAL_TYPE and the runtime error MOVE_TO_LIT_NOTALLOWED_NODATA
  • That the secondary indexes can be updated immediately or late via Lazy Update or Delayed Update

entry.title: Re: Creating the Shell System for SAP Business Transformation Center: A Practical Approach
entry.content:
Hi @rahulrdeo,

Thanks a lot. The approach you described is of course possible and can indeed help to reduce the footprint. I fully understand your point, and there is nothing speaking against it apart from the additional effort it involves. As I mentioned before, it always depends on the specific requirements, and based on those you need to define the best path forward.

Also, you don’t necessarily need to perform a heterogeneous system copy afterwards. You could directly run the SAP S/4HANA conversion based on that first copy, where of course then a HANA database is required. With this approach you would already have your target shell set up on SAP S/4HANA.

Best Regards,
Daniel

entry.title: Re: The attachment content type (Text/xml) not match its...
entry.content:
Thank you for the comment. the error comes from SAP community content filter when you try to attach your XML file. Let me walk you through why this happens.

  • The SAP Community platform checks file extensions against their MIME/content type.
  • In your case:
    • Your file name: ss calculation22.xml
    • Reported content type: text/xml
    • The system decided that the content type did not match the .xml extension and therefore blocked it.
  • This is a known issue on SAP Community where some file types like .xml, .json, .xslt are not supported for direct upload.

Here is my suggested workarounds

  1. Zip your XML File
    • Compress your file into a .zip archive.
    • Upload the .zip instead, this is the most common workaround.
  2. Change your File Extension Temporarily
    • Rename the file to .txt.
    • Mention in your post that it should be renamed back to .xml after download.
  3. Paste Snippet Inline
    • If the XML is small, copy and paste the content directly in your post wrapped in a code block.
  4. Use GitHub / Pastebin / OneDrive
    • Upload your XML file to GitHub Gist, Pastebin, or any company approved file sharing, then share the link in your SAP Community question.

Here is what I recommend, the easiest and clean-core way is to zip the XML file and attach it. That way your content type matches and SAP Community will accept it.

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

entry.title: Re: 🔒 Evolving Security in SAP BTP – Goodbye APIAccess Plan, Hello BTP CLI
entry.content:
Hi @nunocpereira3 ,

Good question. 

For JWT token generation it will also require --idp parameter. Command should look like

btp login --idp "PlatformIDP_Origin_Key" --jwt "<jwt token>"

I tried few scenarios to generate jwt token using postman and pass it in BTP Cli however it fails with error - "Login failed. Check your credentials" 

My understanding is - For platform IDP login (like we do in BTPCLI) it's still not possible to generate a jwt token using Postman or other tools (I tried using few things and it didn't work - it will require an Oauth client to generate it in IAS - it should be IAS Application for BTP Platform IDP however Client Authentication section is disabled for this application). I am using  SAP BTP Trial account which may also have some restrictions and causing issue - not sure.

For Automation - we can use UserID Password and hard code it. This UserID and Password can be maintained in IAS and password can be regulated as per the password policy which we configure.

Screenshot for BTP login using UserID and Password in Platform IDP below:

PS: If anyone is successfully able to generate the jwt token and perform the login - Please feel free to comment here and update !

Regards

entry.title: Re: display arrears wagetype in payslip- Employee central...
entry.content:
Hi @vel 

The issue you mentioned most likely relates to wage type configuration in Employee Central Payroll.

Here are key Points you should Check and how you can Fix it

  1. Cumulation Class in Table V_512W_D
  • Each wage type you want included in Gross must have Cumulation Class 1 set in configuration table V_512W_D.
  • If cumulation class 1 is not flagged, the wage type will be displayed but not cumulated in gross or totals in custom forms.
  • Here is what you can do:
    • Go to transaction SM31 and open view V_512W_D.
    • Find wage type 9070.
    • Set Cumulation class 1 i.e., cumulative into /101 gross wage.
  1. PE51 Form Configuration
  • In your custom payslip, make sure the wage type is included in the window or cumulation group that reads /101 or gross total.
  • If the wage type is only displayed but not part of the calculation for the gross, adjust the cumulation group settings.
  • Also, check if the payslip form or custom logic is referencing the right cumulation wage types for gross and totals.
  1. Processing Class Settings
  • For wage types that should be cumulated and displayed in gross, the processing class settings in their configuration need to precisely match those of other wage types that are correctly summed into gross and total.
  • Ensure you compare wage type 9070’s attributes with similar wage types that are working correctly.
  1. Payroll Simulation and Log
  • Ensure you run payroll simulation for a test employee and check in the payroll log transaction PC_PAYRESULT for wage type 9070.
  • Ensure it is present in the payroll result and that the cumulation wage type /101 includes its value.

 

Evaluate these links for more details.

How to Configure Wage Types in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central Payroll

Wage amount not adding to gross salary

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Not getting GTS SPL screening block for the business...
entry.content:
Hi @Neeraj78 

The issue where your SAP GTS SPL (Sanctioned Party List) screening block is not triggered for business partners who are on the Dow Jones SPL list, due to the presence of the C/O (care of) field in the business partner address coming from ECC to GTS, is a known scenario in GTS master data screening.

Here reasons why this happens

  1. SPL Screening Logic
    • GTS uses address and name parsing rules to generate the screening string.
    • If the C/O field is filled, it may take precedence or alter the matching string.
    • The result of that is, the partner’s main name is either truncated or deprioritized, resulting in mismatch with the Dow Jones list.
  2. Parsing Rules
    • In GTS, parsing rules determine how fields like Name1, Name2, Street, C/O contribute to the string sent to the SPL screening engine.
    • If C/O is included incorrectly, screening may not match even when the BP is on the list.
  3. Data Origin
    • Since the field is being filled in ECC and replicated to GTS, the issue is data-driven.

 

Here are possible Solutions

  1. Adjust SPL Parsing Rules
  • In GTS customizing:
    • SPRO → SAP Global Trade Services → Sanctioned Party List Screening → Define SPL Field Control / Parsing Rules.
    • Check if C/O field is configured as relevant for SPL screening.
    • If yes, you can either:
      • Remove it from SPL relevant parsing.
      • Or move it to a lower-priority field so the main Name1/Name2 has screening precedence.
  1. Field Mapping from ECC to GTS
  • In the BP replication settings, adjust how the C/O field is mapped.
  • You can suppress or overwrite C/O if it is not business critical for SPL screening.
  1. Use BAdI for Screening Data Preparation
  • Implement BAdI /SAPSLL/BADI_SPL_ADDR_PARS, which is the address Parsing BAdI.
  • This lets you cleanse or modify the address data before it is handed over to SPL screening.
  • You can strip or ignore the C/O field values here.
  1. Data Governance
  • If the C/O value is not required for compliance or operational purposes, consider cleaning it up at source to avoid polluting SPL screening.

 

Below is my recommendation

The clean-core approach is:

  • Adjust SPL parsing rules or implement the Address Parsing BAdI to ensure C/O does not override or corrupt the matching string.
  • Keep main Name1/Name2 as the dominant fields for screening.

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: I am not able to see Debit card option.
entry.content:
Hi @Md_inayath 

Currently, SAP Certification Hub only supports credit card payments or invoice in certain regions. The debit card option is not always available, as it depends on your country, payment provider, and SAP’s regional training shop setup.

Suggested Solutions:

Try a Credit Card If you have access, this is the fastest and most widely accepted payment method.

In some countries, SAP allows payment via bank transfer. You will need to contact SAP Training support to request an invoice.

You can raise a ticket directly via the SAP Training Help Center:

SAP Training Help Center – Contact Us

They can confirm which payment methods are available for your location.

Check Country or Region Settings. Make sure you are logged into the correct regional SAP Training Shop. For example: training.sap.com defaults to Global, but you may need to switch to India/EMEA/NA depending on your billing address.

Chris

entry.title: Re: Should SDF for Singapore recalculate in retroactive a...
entry.content:
Hi @SianWray 

The Skills Development Fund  / Skills Development Levy for Singapore payroll should be calculated for the month in which the actual gross wages are paid and not retroactively for prior periods by default. This creates cases where, following a retroactive action like a late onboarding, all arrears from the retro period are included in the SDL calculation only in the current/catch-up month.

How SDL/SDF Calculation Works for Retro Payroll in Singapore

  • SDL is based on wages paid in a given month which may include retro increases or arrears.
  • When there is a retroactive action like onboarding in period 4 for period 3, the SDL is not recalculated for period 3; instead, the retro amount for period 3 is added to the wages in period 4, and SDL is calculated on the total paid in period 4.
  • This behaviour matches the CPF Board’s process for CPF contributions and SDL: calculation is always based on the actual amounts paid out in the period, irrespective of which prior period they relate to.

Is This Correct Functionality?

Yes, under Singapore statutory rules, SDL is calculated on actual paid wages in the pay period when the retro payment is made and not backdated into the prior period. You do not need to and cannot calculate a separate SDF amount for the prior period. It will always reflect in the period when payment is made.

Why Are You Experiencing Under-Contributions?

If you notice under-contribution issues at year end, the common causes may include:

  • Manual corrections or adjustments not paid out in January–December. Only paid wages in each month count.
  • Late onboarding or data entry. Retro payments are cumulated in the payment month, potentially pushing an employee into a higher salary band for that month, but there should not be a gap if every retro amount is processed as part of gross.
  • Misalignment between payroll postings and CPF Board/SDL submission files. Double-check if actual paid wages and SDL reports match what was submitted; discrepancies can cause perceived underpayments.

What You Should Do

  • Ensure that all wage types and retro adjustments are included as gross wages in the SDL calculation for the actual payment month.
  • No action is required to back-calculate SDL for the original retro period; Singapore payroll rules require only that you calculate on payments as paid.
  • Make sure SDL reporting to CPF Board is based on final paid figures and matches payroll records for each calendar month.
  • If reconciling year-end values, sum all paid months’ SDL, including retro payments processed in each month.

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Set Batches for child items of a Sales BOM Item in SA...
entry.content:
Hi @saadsabri 

The error you mentione is a classic limitation when working with Sales BoM non-inventory parent items and batch-managed child items in SAP Business One through the DI API.

Here are the reasons why you get the Error

  • When you add a Sales BoM parent item to the A/R Invoice, SAP B1 expands the BoM and creates the child lines only after the document is added.
  • Batch assignment is required at the child line level not at the parent line but those child lines do not exist in your Document.Lines collection until the system expands the BoM.
  • That is why the DI API throws: Cannot Add Row Without Complete Selection of Batches.

Here are options to Solve the error

  1. Use Draft Document → Then Assign Batches which is the approach you already tested
    • Create the invoice as a Draft with the parent item only.
    • SAP expands the BoM in the draft (child lines appear).
    • Re-load the draft, loop through Document.Lines for the child items, assign batches to the batch-managed ones.
    • Convert the draft to an A/R Invoice.
    • This is the standard safe approach because you work with the expanded structure.
  2. Use Service Layer if available
    • If you are on HANA or SQL with Service Layer, you can send the full JSON payload with parent + child + batch assignments.
    • Unlike DI API, Service Layer allows you to pass child rows explicitly with their batches in one go.
  3. Split Logic: Add Parent, Then Update Document Before Posting
    • This is technically possible but fragile:
      • Add the document with only parent rows so it creates successfully.
      • Immediately re-open it with Documents.GetByKey().
      • Assign batches to the generated child lines and update the document.
    • Drawback: You create a half-baked document and then update. There is a higher risk of posting errors.
  4. Ensure to avoid Manual Child Insertion
    • As you discovered, adding child items manually based on ITT1 only creates extra lines. SAP still expands the BoM on posting.
    • This results in duplicates and will not resolve the batch validation.

Here is my Recommendation

The officially supported and most stable method is either:

  • Draft → Assign batches → Post final invoice, or
  • Use Service Layer where you can control the full payload.

Both approaches are clean-core and avoid difficult workarounds.

SAP Business One DI API 10.0 - Objects Reference (10.00.290)

I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Thank you for sharing your insights.

Few points i noticed - 

1)

From the code updated above - i understand, you are hard coding the value "Germany" as it's maintained as constant. So it will be updating all the users getting synced to target with customattribute1 as Germany?

I understand similar thing will happen in second scenario where CustomAttribute2 will be written as "CustomAttribute2" for every user?

Or will it be working differently? Is it the use case or there will be attributes read from SF or S4hana (mentioned source system)

2)

Also you mentioned that first five customAttributes (customAttribute1 to customAttribute5) are typically reserved for SAC - Teams mapping. So in this scenario - are you using IAS as source system and SAC as target system , so that correct teams are assigned after reading values from Custom attributes from IAS? And from where we will populate them? Request you explain the flow. 

Regards

entry.title: Re: 🔐 Strengthening SAP BTP Security: SSO with Cloud Connector Using Token-Based Auth (Replacing SU
entry.content:
Hi @MatthiasL , 

I think you are talking about this one - https://me.sap.com/notes/0003632133 - 3632133 - Automatic Renewal of Subaccount Certificates in SAP Cloud Connector

This feature is only supported for few subaccounts and Cloud Connector version 2.18.0 or later

Note: The availability of the Auto Renewal feature is region-dependent. If the toggle switch is not visible in the Cloud Connector UI or the SAP BTP cockpit, it indicates that the feature has not yet been activated for that specific cloud region. It will become available once the toggle appears.

How Renewal Works

  • The renewal is triggered n + 7 days before certificate expiry, where n is the alert threshold (configurable in Observation Configuration -> Alerting)
  • If the renewal attempt fails, it is retried every 12 hours
  • If not successful within 7 days, the automatic renewal is cancelled

Customers who are using latest cloud connectors can leverage this functionality.

Regards

entry.title: Re: Issue with Override of Complete Delivery Flag in Sale...
entry.content: @Lakshmipathi — thank you for your quick inputs. As a practical workaround, we are considering not setting the Complete Delivery indicator by default for webshop customers in the master data. Instead, the indicator will be controlled dynamically through the payload — meaning it will only be enabled when specifically required, or left disabled otherwise. This way, the flag is managed flexibly at order creation rather than being enforced globally at the customer level.

entry.title: Re: Mastering Custom Integrations in SAP Datasphere: Leveraging Open Connectors for REST APIs
entry.content:
Hi, thanks for the great blog post!

I followed the steps exactly as described:

  • Installed Integration Suite and Open Connectors

  • response model defined

  • Created the custom connector, created an instance, and tested it → HTTP 200

  • In SAP Datasphere, created and tested the Open Connectors connection → connection works

When I create a Data Flow, I can see the connection and the table. However, as soon as I try to use it I get this error:

Getting dataset definition failed for /spells. HTTP 404: {"requestId":"68ab6129e4b06856503d9995","message":"No object metadata found for 'spells'."}

I’m using the HP API endpoint (/spells) as the source.

entry.content: आप रैपिडो में शिकायत दर्ज करने के लिए निम्नलिखित तरीकों का उपयोग कर सकते हैं: 91 789-6019005 √ आप रैपिडो के ग्राहक सेवा नंबर पर कॉल कर सकते हैं, ऐप में चैट सपोर्ट का उपयोग कर सकते हैं, या ईमेल कर सकते हैं।

entry.title: पैसा डेबिट हुआ लेकिन लेन-देन विफल रहा गूगल पे
entry.content: इसके लिए आपको तुरंत गूगल पे के ग्राहक सहायता टीम से संपर्क करें (0700••825••3013) और अपना ट्रांजेक्शन डिटेल नोट कराए और जल्द से जल्द अपना शिकायत दर्ज करे।

entry.title: Re: Park and Post with workflow for journal entries - Is...
entry.content:
Hello @sivasankarans 

The process you are referring to is indeed delivered via the General Journal Entry Verification workflow scenario WS02800046, together with the related Verify General Journal Entries Fiori apps.

How it works (Maker–Checker principle)

  • A user parks a journal entry using the app Post General Journal Entries – With Workflow (F0718A).
  • The workflow then routes this parked entry to the designated approvers’ My Inbox in Fiori.
  • Once approved, the system automatically posts the journal entry to the ledger.

Configuration Highlights:

  • Activate the workflow via SPRO at:
    Financial Accounting → General Ledger → Document → Document Parking → Define Workflow Settings.
  • Approval rules can be easily set up using the Business Rule Framework plus (BRF+), allowing you to define criteria such as the amount, company code, or cost. This flexible system helps streamline your approval process center.
  • The delivered workflow template WS02800046 can be copied and expanded to suit your organisational requirements.

Key Fiori Apps:

  • Post General Journal Entries – With Workflow
  • Verify General Journal Entries – For Requester
  • My Inbox for workflow task approvals.

References for further details:

  • SAP Help – Workflow for General Journal Entry Verification
  • SAP Community Blogs discussing workflow scenario WS02800046 and its configuration
  • Fiori Apps Library: Manage Workflows for Journal Entry Verification
  • 2962635 - Workflow does not get triggered when posting through App Post General Journal Entries (F0718)

Let me know if you need further support

With kind regards

Chuma
